Thank you to @TWULocal100 for keeping NY moving, and the @nytimes, the @NYTransitMuseum, and the @mta for the stories and the reporting. Photo credit: the New York Transit Museum.

New Yorkers deserve a public transit system that is safe, reliable, and universally accessible to all. 

We build off of the shoulders of those who came before us, like Marion McAllister.

McAllister then needed to go through over a year of training to manage then-new R-44 subway cars, some of which are still in service on the Staten Island Railway.

As she put it: "At first I thought I couldn't take it underground, but now I don't think there's anything better."

From Hollis Park Gardens, Queens, McAllister began working at the MTA in 1969 as a change clerk. 

In 1973, McAllister decided she'd take the test to become what was then known as a "motorman," a train operator. 1,083 men and her took the test that year. 

She placed 19th.

Happy Black History Month! As we near the end of February, I wanted to share the story of Marion McAllister, our subway system's first female train operator.

When we look at the history of NYC's public transit system, we see it is a history shaped by Black New Yorkers.

Medicaid can be confusing, but we can help. Contact us @ 718-545-3889, ad36@nyassembly.gov, or: https://t.co/fQGHgvHbjI

Our office immediately stepped in, and thanks to the advocacy of Constituent Services Director Mariela, our office got her coverage reinstated two months later in March 2023. 

By that time, however, she had already accrued $3,000 in medical transport debt.

My constituent needed medical transport costs covered, something not in her original policy. 

She was wrongly advised to sign up through HRA, but her policy was through the state. She then lost all coverage.

However, she still needed critical medical care & began accruing debt.

In NYC, New Yorkers can sign up for Medicaid through the State or HRA, a city agency.

However, if you sign up for Medicaid or add-on coverage through an agency you didn't originally sign up with, you lose ALL coverage. Additional coverage MUST go through the same admin agency.

In Feb 2023, a disabled constituent in her early 30s needed our help.

Her Medicaid coverage was accidentally terminated. But because she continued to need essential medical care, she accrued thousands in medical debt. 

Here's what happened and how my office stepped in to help.

Alongside universal no-cost childcare, NYC Baby Baskets are part of our comprehensive Family Agenda that will continue to roll out throughout the campaign!

And in a recent US federal government pilot of Newborn Kits based on the baby box model, 64% of moms reported improved mental health, 63% reported a decrease in final stress, and the program doubled participants‚Äô trust in government.

Evidence from long existing models around the world are overwhelmingly positive. 

In Scotland, 91% of families report saving money due to these baskets and 84% read the books provided to their baby, encouraging earlier literacy.

This initiative also dovetails with legislation by @JenGutierrezNYC passed in October by the City Council that requires the Department of Health to develop materials that comprehensively point new parents to resources provided through the city.

The proposal also builds on the work of @ReynosoBrooklyn in tackling maternal mortality and supporting new parents.

"This proposal would build on our 'Born in Brooklyn' baby box pilot," @ReynosoBrooklyn said, "and bring this proven model citywide to help new families meet the challenges of post-partum recovery, financial planning, and the responsibilities of parenthood."
They will also include a resource guide from New York City that includes information on the Newborn Home Visiting Program, breastfeeding and post-partum depression.

Each NYC Baby Basket will include items like:

üçº diapers
üçº perineal spray
üçº baby wipes
üçº nursing pads 
üçº diaper changing mats
üçº post-partum pads
üçº burping cloths
üçº swaddles 
üçº books 

And more as developed by experts at @nycHealthy!

Commonly known as a ‚Äúbaby box,‚Äù the concept originated a century ago in Finland, where it‚Äôs now a universal program. 

Scotland +Chile also provide them to every new family.

There are 91+ programs around the world + our federal government recently concluded a successful pilot.

More information on the Steinways and the history of socialism in Western Queens can be found at @lichistory.
Intending to build a socialist-inspired utopia for his workers, Steinway built a community that eventually became known as "Steinway Village."

He built homes, places of worship, schools, and libraries, plus a post office and transit network for his workers.

The neighborhood even had an amusement park known as ‚Äúthe Coney Island of Queens" that was open from 1895-1915.

In 1870 William Steinway moved his family‚Äôs piano factory to Queens and purchased some nearby farmland. 

Steinway also became determined to meaningfully accommodate his workers at a standard far greater than what was the norm of the time. https://t.co/QiRgqWAZMT

The Steinway piano, subway stop, and street all trace back to a single family: the Steinways.

Making a name for itself selling pianos, the Steinways also had a hand in building one of Astoria's first socialist communities.

@LIChistory Astor stayed in Manhattan but agreed to give Stephen $500 (~$18,000 today).

On April 12, 1839, the New York State Legislature passed a bill incorporating the Village of Astoria, leading to the ‚ÄúAstoria‚Äù we know today.

@LIChistory Through the fur trade, Halsey was acquainted with John Jacob Astor, a well-known fur trader. 

Looking to encourage Astor to live in and contribute to the community, Halsey offered to name Hallet's Cove after Astor.

@LIChistory After 1 year, he moved to Astoria, then known as Hallet's Cove. With the help of his older brother John, Stephen bought most of the land between Pot Cove & Hallet's Cove. By 1840, he molded the area into a village with streets, houses, & stores.

But it's not called Halsia. Why?

@LIChistory The Halsey family, originally from New England, moved to NYC and got involved in the fur business in the 1830s.

In 1834, Stephen bought a home in Flushing. As he commuted to New York by steamboat, he couldn‚Äôt help but notice the beautifully green Astoria peninsula by Hell Gate.

Our first collaborative post with @lichistory is about Stephen Alling Halsey.

Halsey, a merchant born on April 7, 1798, is widely credited as being the ‚ÄúFather of Astoria.‚Äù

But it‚Äôs not for the reason you might think.¬†üßµ

My office has spent the last 1.5 years as a party in the state's rate case, arguing for a rejection of ConEd's proposal and for a rate reduction.

We cannot allow New Yorkers to be priced out of their basic human rights to cook, heat and light their homes.

We must take essential rights like energy out of the market for profit and instead build publicly owned, and democratically controlled, power.

In the coming months, Governor Hochul‚Äôs Public Service Commission will decide whether to approve this proposal.

State commissions like the PSC cannot continue to operate as rubber-stamps for ConEd‚Äôs requests to increase profits on the backs of working class NYers.

My office has been advocating for a rate reduction throughout this rate case (which we‚Äôve been in negotations for) and I have refused to sign this agreement.

We are in the middle of a cost of living crisis, with NYers already seeing a 32.7% increase in energy costs from 2021-‚Äò22

No matter how much energy you use, fixed charges will increase 18% for electric and 20-34% for gas. 

The billions made on the backs of consumers will go towards wildly increasing @ConEdison's rate of return on their investments, and to building out fossil fuel infrastructure.

As calculated by @UtilityProject, the proposal means that the average residential customer will see electric bills increase by $18/ 
month, heating gas bills by $40.60/month, and cooking gas bill by $6/month over the next 3 years, not to mention higher monthly fixed charges.

ConEd & state regulators have proposed a deal to raise gas + electric bills for the average residential customer by $60+ / month by 2026. 

This proposal is a slap in the face to working class New Yorkers and a reminder of the relationship of the state to corporations like ConEd.

What happened to Kalief is not "public safety" 

The Gov's proposal guts Kalief's Law ‚Äî bringing us back to the process that ultimately took his life & squashes the progress we've made since

@GovKathyHochul must honor Kalief

No rollbacks: lives depend on it

The Law also recognized the defendant's right to know all the discovery so they can make informed decisions on how to plead

Kalief faced immense pressure to plead guilty ‚Äî he deserved to know what evidence the prosecution held against him

And that right is being stripped too

Kalief's Law ties discovery to the right to a speedy trial ‚Äî a right that Kalief never got

Now @GovKathyHochul is untying the two:

Instead of ALL discovery, her proposal only requires "substantial compliance" ‚Äî a subjective measure bringing us back to pre-Kalief's Law times

Kalief's Law, passed in 2019, made sure that the prosecution could only declare they are "ready for trial" once they have handed over ALL discovery (the evidence that will be used in trial)

This wasn‚Äôt the case for Kalief

As a result he sat on Rikers for YEARS on a minor arrest

The carceral system treats people as guilty until proven innocent

Kalief had allegedly stolen a backpack ‚Äî he was held for 3 years, 2 in solitary, abused by officers & constantly asked to plead guilty

Kalief's Law was created to honor his wish that no one would face what he did

Kalief Browder, 16, spent 3 yrs on Rikers & 2 yrs in solitary awaiting trial

Let's be clear ‚Äî he died by suicide, but it was the state that took his life

He didn't want this to happen to anyone else, that's why we passed Kalief's Law

It's up to @GovKathyHochul to honor him üßµ https://t.co/Z7J2pcUdkw

Her child was born and she continued to pursue her PhD ‚Äî but, when she was about to finish she was forced to drop out to work more hours & support her family

‚ÄúWhat's driving me is making a good future for students, professors, and everyone at Hunter‚Äù

When big landlords use housing as speculative investments, both small homeowners and tenants have to leave their homes and our neighborhood

#GoodCause eviction is a bill that asserts that we have a right to housing, and a right to stay in our neighborhood

Small landlords & tenants both face financial pressure caused by large, predatory landlords & corporate mgmt companies

A constituent that lives in his family home by Astoria Park tells us that it‚Äôs not uncommon to receive ‚Äúwe buy homes‚Äù flyers in his mailbox from such landlords

Under #GoodCause, landlords would have to justify rent increases above 3% or 150% CPI (whichever is higher) 

Fair justification can be things like increased costs, property taxes, or capital repairs

One of the landlords who came into our office to fill out their portion of the ERAP application had the same tenant for 30 years and told us that they only raise their tenants' rents in correspondence to other increased costs

#GoodCause DOES give tenants a defense against arbitrary eviction after the term of their lease expires

A small landlord we spoke to asked about ERAP so they wouldn't have to evict: "finding new tenants is time-consuming and expensive, we don't want to evict unless we have to"

For those that aren‚Äôt exempt, small landlords tend to use eviction for two main cases: 
- if a tenant isn‚Äôt paying rent
- if a tenant breaks the terms of their lease

#GoodCause DOESN‚ÄôT protect tenants against eviction in either of these cases

Our office has been working with several small landlords to apply for ERAP ‚Äì mostly POC & immigrant senior homeowners

Most of these homeowners would be EXEMPT from Good Cause eviction because they live in the building they are renting out and it has fewer than 4 units

#GoodCause gives market rate tenants the ability to defend their right to stay in their home after their lease expires & give tenants the ability to defend themselves against unreasonable rent increases (>150% CPI)

From all the calls our office received asking for more information about the Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP), 1/4 were from small landlords asking on behalf of their tenants

Here is what small landlords in Astoria are facing & how #GoodCause would affect them üßµ

5. TENANT SAFE HARBOR ACT

passed June 2020, gives tenants a defense in eviction court if:
- they faced COVID-19 related financial hardship &
- owe rent due between 3/7/20 - 1/15/22 

If successful, a tenant can stay in their home but will still owe money to their landlord

4. RIGHT TO COUNSEL
Tenants facing eviction in Housing Court or NYCHA administrative have access to free legal representation & advice, regardless of immigration status

Call 311 and ask for the Right to Counsel to be connected with free legal services

A. If funds become available, they will be distributed by first come/first serve

B. A landlord cannot move forward with the eviction process while your application is being processed

C. If your app is approved, a landlord cannot evict you without good cause for 1 year

We've gotten questions about if there are funds available for those in our neighborhood because this disclaimer appears on OTDA's website üëá

Although funds are not currently projected to be available for NYC/Queens County, we are still asking our constituents to apply https://t.co/YsgxsGwnbD

3. EMERGENCY RENTAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (ERAP)

If you have not applied to the Emergency Rental Assistance Program but are eligible (including being behind on rent/utility payments due to COVID hardship) please apply.

The portal reopened last week: https://t.co/4c1Qy0mEZL

2. ILLEGAL LOCKOUTS

If your landlord illegally locks you out of your home, call 911 ‚Äî the police are supposed to cut the locks & let you back in

However, we've seen issues where police don't help tenants, if that happens please call our office (718) 545-3889 so we can support

You have the right to stay in your home until you receive an Eviction Order signed by a Judge and delivered by a Marshal or Sheriff

If you are unsure if paperwork you received is an official Eviction Order, call 311 and ask for the Tenant Helpline to get more information

1. DO NOT SELF-EVICT
We‚Äôve already heard about landlords in our neighborhood using harassment & other tactics to get tenants to leave ‚Äî it's illegal to pressure or force someone to leave their home

This includes illegal lockouts, shutting off utilities, and fake eviction notices

The NYS eviction moratorium expired on January 15th, which means eviction cases can now proceed in court

For the 4M NYers who live in unregulated housing, they have no rights against these sorts of arbitrary evictions

The Emergency Rental Assistance Program is insufficient:
- 590k households are still behind on rent
- Only 286k households were able to apply & only 165k approved
- Around 175k eligible households weren‚Äôt aware of it
- NYS requested 1B in additional fed funds & received only 27M

TSHA gives tenants a defense in eviction court if
- they faced COVID-19 related financial hardship &
- they are behind on rent since March 7, 2020

If successful in court, a tenant can stay in their home but will still owe money to their landlord ‚Äî known as a ‚Äúmonetary judgement‚Äù

There are currently 255,000 pending cases in NYS eviction court

On January 15th, the eviction moratorium will expire, and thousands will be at risk of losing their homes

Two vital pieces of leg will prevent a crisis of eviction: the Tenant Safe Harbor Act & #GoodCause üßµ

Today, thanks to the leadership and relentless organizing of @NYTWA, and through solidarity with each other, we finally got drivers what they deserve

There is so much more to say but thank you to all those who came out to support at Broadway & Murray & made this fight their own

Details of the agreement:
- A city-backed taxi medallion guarantee
- $170,000 maximum debt
- 5% interest rate
- payments of ~$1100/month

For the avg driver that is currently $550k in debt, this changes everything.

We won.

On our 15th day of hunger strike, we got word that @NYTWA has reached an agreement with the City.

This amazing news means our drivers can live a future free of the devastation of the debt crisis.

END/

5/ This is no surprise.

CSS found MIH favors higher income levels, leaving behind low income families‚Äîprimarily those of color.

3/ The rezoning is ‚Äúupzoning‚Äù ‚Äî creating denser development ‚Äî and triggers Mandatory Inclusionary Housing (MIH).

MIH is a city program that requires developers who benefit from upzoning to make some units permanently affordable.

2/ In Astoria, 44% of our neighbors are rent-burdened, spending at least 30% of their monthly income on rent.

This rezoning would build 72 units of affordable housing, while the rest (75%) will be market rate.

MYTH: The market is responsible for this crisis

FACT:
The City Council investigation deemed that the City was responsible ‚Äî from actively inflating medallion values to allowing ride-share companies to flood the market

MYTH: The City's current plan will give drivers affordable loan rates

FACT:
City's plan: drivers pay $1,500-$2,000/mo & avg. driver owes $330k (3x the market value of a medallion) ‚Äî Not affordable!

@NYTWA's plan: drivers pay $800/mo & owe a MAX of $145,000 (around market rate)

MYTH: The plan will take too long to be implemented

FACT:
The Chief Financial Officer of the City says the NYTWA plan ‚Äúcan be implemented without delay‚Äù

The Mayor releases a financial plan 4x/yr & the next plan is due by November 1 ‚Äî the City & TLC can get this done by then

MYTH: @NYTWA's plan is too expensive

FACT:
The City‚Äôs Chief Financial Officer called the @NYTWA plan ‚Äúthe most strategic and comprehensive roadmap we have to relieve crushing debt, resolve non-performing loans, and save taxpayer money‚Äù
2/2

MYTH: @NYTWA's plan is too expensive

FACT:
At most, it would cost $93M over 30yrs ‚Äî based on driver default rate at the peak of the medallion crisis

Less than HALF of what the City spends on housing police in 1 yr

Non-criminal (also called technical) violations ‚Äî things like missing curfew or changing residence without approval ‚Äî have sent thousands to Rikers for decades

When Less is More is implemented, parolees can no longer be sent to jail for these sorts of minor violations

Both Thomas & Jose were held on Rikers for alleged shoplifting ‚Äî a low-level misdemeanor

They died awaiting trial

Under NY‚Äôs parole laws, a criminal court judge couldn't have released them if they‚Äôd wanted to

Less is More gives judges discretion to grant their release

Impeachment is a process, and one of the best tools for us to hold our leaders accountable.

The AG's report means we must commence this process, but there must be enough pressure ‚Äî both from the public and legislators ‚Äî to commence impeachment proceedings.  #ImpeachCuomo

If removed from office, Lt. Gov. @KathyHochul will serve the rest of Cuomo‚Äôs term.

Impeachment does not bar Cuomo from running for office again.

What votes are required for impeachment?

(1) A majority vote of the 150-member assembly 

(2) A two-thirds majority vote of 69-member impeachment court, made up of 62 Senators (excluding Majority Leader) and 7 Court of Appeals‚Äô judges, the state‚Äôs highest court
FOUR: Conviction or Acquittal. A 2/3 majority of the impeachment court is needed to convict
THREE: A trial is commenced if a majority of members of the impeachment court do not object to the sufficiency of the articles of impeachment & the Governor does not plead guilty

TWO: An Impeachment Court is Formed. Consisting of a majority of: 62 Senators (excluding Majority Leader Andrea Stewart-Cousins), 7 Court of Appeals‚Äô judges (the state‚Äôs highest court), with the Chief Judge as the presiding judge

What is the impeachment process?

ONE: The 150-member Assembly must pass articles of impeachment by a simple majority of at least 76 votes. If they pass, Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul will temporarily act as governor

The first & only governor to be impeached was William Sulzer, 1913

Then, the prevailing wisdom was that a gov could be impeached on any basis the legislature found appropriate

That was codified in a 1913 court case determining that no law can impede the leg's right to impeach

What is an impeachable offense? 

NYS's constitution gives the legislature broad and unconstrained powers to impeach

Unlike at the federal level, there is no constitutional standard for impeachment

For precedent, let‚Äôs take a look at the 1st and only NY gov to be impeached ‚¨áÔ∏è

It‚Äôs common sense ‚Äî hold ALL candidates to the same contribution limits ‚Äî regardless of if they come from wealthy families

Eliminating this is a step towards reckoning with the racist history of generational wealth

Thank you to the CUNY students for their research & those formerly incarcerated people for their interviews.

Thank you for your organizing. We must divest in Corcraft.

Read more about Stephanie and the accounts of other incarcerated workers here:
https://t.co/ZDCCW2StWB

Divestment is a step to reducing our reliance on the prison-industrial complex for our everyday existence

But our prison system relies on dehumanization and brutality, so the goal must be to abolish this exploitative system entirely.

We must #DecarcerateNow

There is no option for ethical consumption ‚Äî if you live in New York, you‚Äôve used Corcraft products

And so there is no other answer than to divest in Corcraft ‚Äî what students are demanding that CUNY do.

Corcraft products include the hand-sanitizer distributed by the state, the filing cabinets in our Albany office, the desks at CUNY, grills for state parks, and the trash cans on our sidewalks. 

These products built with exploited prison labor are ubiquitous across our state.

One formerly incarcerated person, Stephanie Foxworth, spent long days lifting heavy sheets of metal ‚Äî dangerous and difficult work.

Her starting wage was 16 cents an hour. 

At that rate, it would take her three-and-a-half hours of labor to buy a 55-cent postage stamp.

Corcraft, also known as the New York State (NYS) Division of Correctional Industries, is a state-run prison labor corporation that operates a range of enterprises in 13 prisons across New York State

Corcraft products are then often purchased by the state & public institutions

Yesterday @AbolitionAtCUNY and @RAPPcampaign held a press conference to demand that @CUNY divest from Corcraft NOW

If you're a NYer you've probably used Corcraft products ‚Äî ones built with labor from incarcerated people being paid far less than $1/hr üßµ

Marijuana legalization is an issue of racial & economic justice

Legislation like this must be written with a lens to decarceration ‚Äî thank you @CPeoplesStokes for your championing

We must continue to fight for justice & to dismantle our broken carceral system

MRTA also ensures that a criminal record will not be created for a young person that uses marijuana & implements a drug education program for those under 21 that use

Unlike Cuomo's CRTA, MRTA is written knowing that our carceral system is more damaging than marijuana use

MRTA is expected to create $350 million in new revenue to be used for things like education funding, legal & mental health services, re-entry services for those released for cannabis-related crimes, and support for businesses started by those who have suffered from prohibition

MRTA gives extra priority to those who suffer most from cannabis prohibition including:

Those from communities with disproportionately incarcerated due to prohibition

Those under 80% median income of their county

Those previously convicted of cannabis-related offenses

CRTA also would increase criminal penalties than current law:

It would increase the punishment for driving under the influence from an A misdemeanor to an E felony. 

MRTA doesn‚Äôt increase penalties from existing law.

Here is just one example: 

CRTA would impose additional civil penalties for the possession of ‚Äúillicit‚Äù cannabis, with the highest penalty being up to $4000/ilicit plant. 

MTRA does not pose additional civil penalties.

In Jan, Gov. Cuomo reintroduced the Cannabis Regulation and Taxation Act (CRTA) proposing a framework to regulate medical, adult-use and hemp cannabis

Advocates, like those at @startsmartNY, called it a ‚Äúbackwards move‚Äù from 2019‚Äôs marijuana
decriminalization and expungement law

MRTA allows the use of marijuana by those 21+ within a tightly regulated system, improves the medical marijuana program, expands hemp farming, & regulates all aspects of cannabis under the Office of Cannabis Management.

It's markedly different than @NYGovCuomo 's proposal, CRTA

2 weeks ago we passed MRTA to legalize marijuana in NY‚Äî a step in dismantling our carceral system

While @NYGovCuomo signed it into law & tries to take credit: MTRA is not his legislation

His proposal was far more punitive & would criminalize those affected most by prohibitionüßµ

So who does Vienna have to thank for making "housing as a human right" a workable policy?

Finally, here's what you can do tonight:

Join us for a post-campaign debrief tonight at 7pm on Zoom. You'll here from me, our communications director, and our campaign manager about what we achieved, what we still need to do, and how you can help. https://t.co/jxy4IYzphs (7/7)

We will be conducting a training on how to be an observer this Monday, June 29th at 7pm.

We're going to need about 15 in-person volunteers per day during this critically important process, so if you're available, please RSVP. https://t.co/PflZu5ZkD7 (6/7)

Beginning on July 1st, the Board of Elections will start the process of opening and counting absentee ballots.

We need volunteers to help us observe this process and make sure that all relevant rules and procedures are being observed. (5/7)

The takeaway: Assemblymember Simotas would need to beat us by 12 points among the absentee votes in order to take the lead.

Here's what the next steps are: (4/7)

We can see this in the age breakdown of absentee ballots requested in our district. 

The largest age cohort requesting absentee ballots were voters aged 25-34, and the second largest cohort was voters aged 35-49. We believe these ballots are likely to favor us.

Normally, the absentee vote is more hostile to the progressive candidate than the in-person vote.

However, we think this will not be the case this year, given that many people who normally vote in-person decided to vote by absentee due to the pandemic. (3/7)

There are about 5,000 absentee ballots that still need to be counted. The Board of Elections won't start opening and counting these ballots until July 1st.

That shouldn't take more than a week, so we expect to have a good idea of the outcome by the second week of July. (2/7)

We're in the lead, and we feel good.

Here's where things stand as of today:

The early vote and the same-day, in-person vote have been tabulated. After this, we are up 4,228 to 3,639. That's a margin of 589 votes, or 7.5 percent. (1/7)

Another world is possible, one where instead of consigning people to the violence of incarceration, we create space for them to heal and thrive. @phara4assembly, @MarcelaforNy, @JabariBrisport, @BorisSantosBK & I pledge to help build that world together, starting in New York.

Finally, we pledge to abide by the principles articulated in the No New Jails electoral pledge. We'll fight the construction of new carceral facilities and advocate instead for investment in those communities that have been most impacted by mass incarceration.

These policies would help roll back the worst excesses of carceral violence, but deeper change is still needed.

That's why we'll introduce legislation to establish a sentencing reform commission with a mandate to reduce NY‚Äôs incarceration rate to its 1950 level within 10 years.

We will also introduce new decarceral legislation to:

üåπDecriminalize simple drug possession
üåπRepeal all mandatory minimum sentences
üåπReduce maximum sentences w/ retroactive effect
üåπRepeal felony bump-up statutes
üåπRepeal sentencing enhancements
üåπEnd cooperation with ICE

We will support existing decarceral legislation that will:

üåπEnd cash bail
üåπRepeal the "walking while trans" ban
üåπDecriminalize sex work
üåπLegalize marijuana
üåπPermit safe injection sites
üåπRestrict solitary confinement
üåπEnact elder parole
üåπRe-enfranchise incarcerated NYers

Some people want to roll back even the mild bail reforms NY adopted last year. We can't let them.

In fact, we need to push further. NY's brutal system of mass incarceration goes far beyond cash bail.

This election isn‚Äôt about a single candidate ‚Äî it‚Äôs about a movement.

As a democratic socialist, I know that we‚Äôll never win the rights we all deserve - healthcare, housing, education, nutrition, childcare, & public power - w/o a grassroots movement rising up to demand them.

I‚Äôm running bc it‚Äôs time to guarantee housing to all NYers regardless of ability to pay. 

It‚Äôs time to desegregate our schools, fully eliminate cash bail, ban solitary confinement, fund & fix the MTA, & fight for social, racial, econ. & envir. justice for the many, not the few.

I‚Äôm running because, like 24% of my neighbors, I‚Äôm spending 50% of my income on rent.

And yet, there is nothing preventing our landlords from refusing to renew our leases, evicting us w/o good cause, or even from increasing our rents beyond a conscionable amount.

When ppl come to me in a crisis, all I can point them to are small grants, low-interest loans, & GoFundMes.

And no matter how many people we‚Äôre able to help, there are always 1000s more across Queens on the precipice of homelessness because of an illness, job loss or emergency.

I‚Äôm running for NY State Assembly here in Astoria and I‚Äôm doing it bc I spend each day at work coming up against the legacy of Albany‚Äôs bankrupt policies.

Our reps have turned family homes into investment properties while letting public housing fall into decay and disrepair.
